Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Negative Pressure Wound Therapy for Subcutaneous Abdominal Wound Healing Impairment

Trial_Design.evidence: Adult patients with SAWHI after surgery were randomly assigned to NPWT or CWT in a 1:1 ratio using a centralized web-based tool.

Participants.evidence: Adult patients with SAWHI after surgery were randomly assigned to NPWT or CWT in a 1:1 ratio using a centralized web-based tool.

Intervention.evidence: negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT) compared to conventional wound treatment (CWT)

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the effectiveness and safety of negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT) compared to conventional wound treatment (CWT) for SAWHI.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was time to wound closure within 42 days.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was stratified by study site and wound size, with allocation concealment ensured.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 539 patients were randomized between August 2, 2011, and January 31, 2018

Number_Analysed.evidence: 507 included in the modified intention-to-treat analysis (NPWT, 256; CWT, 251).

Result_Outcome.evidence: Mean time to wound closure was significantly shorter in the NPWT arm (36.1 days) compared to the CWT arm (39.1 days) (difference, 3.0 days; 95% CI, 1.6-4.4; P < 0.001).

Harms.evidence: The risk of wound-related adverse events was higher in the NPWT arm (risk ratio, 1.51; 95% CI, 0.99-2.35).
